sections.facts: A police officer seized a motor vehicle that the respondent had recently bought from the appellant, suspecting it to be stolen. Subsequent investigation confirmed the suspicion, and the vehicle was returned to its rightful owner. The respondent then instituted an action against the appellant for damages under the statutory warranty against eviction granted to buyers. At trial the only point in dispute was whether the respondent's claim was prescribed.
sections.issues: The sole issue was the correct commencement date of the prescription period for the respondent's claim, i.e., when the debt became due and the creditor acquired knowledge of the debtor's identity and the relevant facts.
sections.principles: The court relied on sections 12(1) and 12(3) of the Prescription Act 68 of 1969, which state that prescription begins when a debt becomes due and, for claims based on knowledge, when the creditor knows the identity of the debtor and the facts giving rise to the claim.
sections.application: Applying the Act, the court determined that the respondent became aware of the appellant's liability at the time the vehicle was handed back and the damage claim arose. Consequently, the prescription period had not yet expired, and the claim was timely.
sections.conclusion: The appeal was dismissed, and the lower court's finding in favour of the respondent was upheld. The respondent's claim was not prescribed.
